channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Deadly Strikes Hit Key Southern City as Russia Restores Some Traffic on Damaged Bridge
item.description: Less than a day after an explosion damaged Moscow’s bridge to Crimea, Russian missiles again hit residential areas of Zaporizhzhia, local officials said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: The West Has a Migration Crisis. Why Does Rwanda Want to Help?
item.description: The small African nation has positioned itself as an altruistic partner of wealthier countries seeking to curb migration. But experts say Rwanda’s human rights record makes it no refuge for asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Emergency Transit Mechanism Center in Gashora, Rwanda, houses African refugees awaiting asylum or resettlement elsewhere.

item.title: Why Thailand’s Strict Gun Laws Did Not Keep It Safe
item.description: Firearm policy is tough for some people and lax for others, a recipe for problems. The horrific attack by an ex-policeman may spur calls for change, but it will not be easy.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Muktita Suhartono and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Andre Malerba for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners at Wat Rat Samakee, a temple in Naklang, Thailand, on Saturday, two days after a mass killing in and around a day care center. The attacker’s gun was obtained legally, the police said.

item.title: Deadly Shooting at Israeli Checkpoint Sets Jerusalem on Edge
item.description: Surging violence claimed the lives of four Palestinians and an Israeli soldier over the weekend, raising tensions on the eve of a Jewish holiday.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli security forces are seen after a deadly shooting at a checkpoint late Saturday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Greece Tries Stationing Police on Campus, and Students Fight Back
item.description: For decades, law enforcement was rarely allowed on university grounds. Critics say that putting officers there is part of a slide toward authoritarianism.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Officers used tear gas in Athens last month to disperse students protesting the newly established university police force.

item.title: An American in Ukraine Finds the War He’s Been Searching For
item.description: For an unconventional former Marine colonel, Ukraine represents the morally just war that eluded him his entire career. But how much can he and his military start-up help?
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Milburn, founder of The Mozart Group, with Richie, a rescued mutt who has become the group’s mascot.

item.title: After Secret US Talks Fail, A Hidden War in Africa Rapidly Escalates
item.description: Months of discreet American diplomacy have failed to stop the fighting in northern Ethiopia. Now, the civil war is plunging into its most alarming phase yet.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Ireland Opens Decades of Secret Records to Adoptees
item.description: Thousands of people are being promised new rights to information, a potentially momentous step in a country where unmarried mothers were pressured for decades to give up their babies.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shrine honoring children interred at a mother and baby home in Tuam, Ireland, from 1925 to 1961. A local historian traced hundreds of deaths there.

item.title: In Record Numbers, Venezuelans Risk a Deadly Trek to the U.S. Border
item.description: Two crises are converging at the perilous land bridge known as the Darién Gap: the economic and humanitarian disaster underway in South America, and the bitter fight over immigration policy in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Former Gov. Bill Richardson ‘Cautiously Optimistic’ About Griner’s Release
item.description: Bill Richardson, the former ambassador to the U.N., has been at odds with the White House over his private talks with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:description: Bill Richardson in New York City in November of last year.

item.title: Russia Rushes to Restore Traffic After Crimea Bridge Explosion
item.description: An explosion a day earlier partly damaged the span and embarrassed the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Passenger cars driving on the Kerch bridge, after an explosion destroyed part of it, in the Kerch Strait, Crimea, on Sunday.

item.title: North Korea’s Threat
item.description: Frustrated and isolated, the North is conducting more missile tests than ever.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A North Korean missile test in 2017.

item.title: Blast on Crimean Bridge Deals Blow to Russian War Effort in Ukraine
item.description: Any impediment to traffic on the bridge could affect Russia’s ability to wage war in southern Ukraine, where Ukraine’s forces have been fighting an increasingly effective counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Black smoke billowed from a fire on the Kerch Strait Bridge that links Crimea to Russia on Friday.

item.title: 10 Dead in Gas Station Explosion in Ireland, Officials Say
item.description: A child and two teenagers were among those killed after an explosion in Creeslough, County Donegal, on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The police said a girl, a teenage boy, a teenage girl, three women and four men died in the explosion in Creeslough.

item.title: Four Russian Missiles Strike Center of Kharkiv
item.description: Two building complexes used by the Ukrainian military appeared to be the targets.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers cleaned up debris after a piece of a shot-down missile fell into a park opposite its primary target, in central Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: The Purpose of Extra-Large Marshmallows? A U.K. Court Weighs In
item.description: A British tribunal considered how a slightly larger marshmallow might be taxed by evaluating its taste, size and packaging.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A British tax tribunal examined marshmallows in detail, finding that ones slightly larger in size are “equally palatable” as a snack or roasted.

item.title: Many Canadians Can’t Afford Homes Despite Cooling Real Estate Market
item.description: Even in cities that were once considered a good bet for house hunters seeking affordability, affluent households find that prices are high.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nippun Goyal, 35, left, and his wife, Ritu Choudhary, 31, packing up their condo in Toronto for the move to Hamilton.

item.title: Children Killed in Thailand Massacre Are Laid to Rest
item.description: The town of Uthai Sawan in Thailand, a Buddhist-majority country, began formally mourning the victims of a mass killing at a day care center, most of them children.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.media:credit: Andre Malerba for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Happy Birthday, Mr. President’: Ukrainians Celebrate Bridge Blast With Memes.
item.description: The bridge has both practical and symbolic resonance.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A couple took a selfie in front of an artwork shaped as a big stamp named “Cotton to the Crimean Bridge.

item.title: Russia Names a New General to Lead Forces in Ukraine
item.description: General Surovikin, 55, had been leading troops in Ukraine’s south, where Kyiv’s forces have been waging a counteroffensive to reclaim territory from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Gen. Sergei Surovikin in 2017.

item.title: A Yayoi Kusama Pumpkin Sculpture Is Reinstalled in Japan
item.description: Technically, it’s a replica of the polka-dot plastic creation that was damaged by a storm last year. But regardless, people are happy.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives

item.title: Page Turners
item.description: Fall is the perfect time to hunker down and read deeply.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Hockey Canada Scandal: Rethinking How Sports Are Governed
item.description: Defiant testimony from the organization’s interim chairwoman prompted a widespread backlash this week from both Parliament and corporate sponsors.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The Hockey Canada scandal drove fans away from the junior world championship in August.

item.title: Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Loses Power Again, Officials Say
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, on the Dnipro River, has been occupied by Russian forces since early March.

item.title: Egypt’s New Administrative Capital Rises, but at What Price?
item.description: It is the grandest in a slew of megaprojects spearheaded by the president. But as the country limps through a dire economic crisis, there are doubts about whether it can afford his grandiose dreams.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: The future business district in Egypt’s new capital, a megaproject just outside Cairo, in 2021.

item.title: Crimea’s Kerch Bridge Holds Deep Value for Putin and Russia
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia presided over the bridge’s opening, personally driving a truck across the link between Russia and Crimea — land seized from Ukraine in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The Kerch Strait Bridge in Crimea in 2019.

item.title: A Distracted Russia Is Losing Its Grip on Its Old Soviet Sphere
item.description: Russia’s domination of Central Asia and the Caucasus region is unraveling as the Kremlin focuses on the war in Ukraine — and border violence is flaring.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Seeks ‘Off-Ramp’ to Putin’s Nuclear Threat, Warning of Potential ‘Armageddon’
item.description: President Biden has mused publicly on whether there might be an “off-ramp” for nuclear threats from the Russian leader that invoke Cold War rhetoric.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden said on Thursday the world may be facing “the prospect of Armageddon” if President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia uses a tactical nuclear weapon.

item.title: The I.M.F. said $1.3 billion in emergency funding for Ukraine had been approved by its board.
item.dc:creator: Juston Jones
item.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said the financing was approved under a new program to address food shortages.

item.title: Haiti Appeals for Armed Intervention and Aid to Quell Chaos
item.description: Prime Minister Ariel Henry and his government asked the international community to step in, largely to control gang violence that has ravaged the capital.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Protesters this week in Port-au-Prince, where gang violence has spun out of control.

item.title: Its Army in Retreat, Russia Strikes Multiple Ukrainian Cities
item.description: On Vladimir V. Putin’s 70th birthday, his faltering military continued to show that it could use its advantage in long-range munitions to rain death and destruction far from the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Volunteers removing rubble and looking for survivors after a strike in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Winners Share a Past Shadowed by Russian Abuses
item.description: Democracy advocates from Belarus, Russia and Ukraine were jointly awarded the world’s most prestigious peace prize, an implicit condemnation of the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine and repression at home.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Freitas/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A picture of the jailed Belarus rights activist Ales Bialiatski, one of this year’s Nobel Peace Prize winners, is placed next to previous laureates in the garden of the Nobel Institute in Oslo, Norway.

item.title: A mass grave and a separate burial site with nearly 200 bodies are discovered in Lyman.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Forensic technicians were exhuming and trying to identify bodies at a burial site in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: US Targets Businessmen and Companies in New North Korea Sanctions
item.description: The Biden administration is bracing for Kim Jong-un to carry out a nuclear test. It says North Korea has fired 41 ballistic missiles this year, including one over Japan.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: A screen showing images of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, during a news update in Tokyo on Tuesday. North Korea’s missile launch prompted an alert in Japan that morning.

item.title: Easter Island ‘Moai’ Statues Damaged Beyond Repair in Fire
item.description: The fire has burned more than 247 acres of the Pacific island, where hundreds of haunting monolithic statues, called moai, have stood for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Rapanui Municipality/Getty Images
item.media:description: Many ancient monolithic statues, called moai, have been damaged in a fire in Rapa Nui National Park on Easter Island.

item.title: After Day Care Massacre, Thailand Is Roiled With Grief
item.description: Anguished families were coming to terms with the loss of their young children as the nation pondered issues like gun violence and the widespread availability of deadly weapons.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee, Ryn Jirenuwat and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Andre Malerba for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners pray at the gates of the day care center at the Uthai Sawan subdistrict office on Friday in Nong Bua Lamphu, Thailand.

item.title: White House Tightens Rules on Counterterrorism Drone Strikes
item.description: A classified new policy requires President Biden’s approval to add suspected terrorists to a kill list. The Trump administration had decentralized control over targeting decisions.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An Air Force Predator drone, right, returning from a mission in the Persian Gulf region in 2016. The new policy suggests that the United States intends to launch fewer drone strikes away from recognized war zones.

item.title: Shelling again damages power lines at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in early September, amid the ongoing Russian military action in Ukraine. Shelling in the region has interrupted electricity to reactors for the second time in two weeks.

item.title: Memorial Shed Light on Russia’s Past and Current Repressions
item.description: Members of the group have paid for their work with their lives and their freedom.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Anton Troianovski
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Members of rights group Memorial hold a press conference in Moscow in November 2021.

item.title: Liverpool Will Host 2023 Eurovision Song Contest
item.description: The popular competition would have been held in Ukraine, which won this year’s event, but safety concerns sent it to Britain instead.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine earned the right to host next year’s event after winning this year’s contest in May, but it was ruled out by Eurovision organizers.

item.title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Exposes Old Fault Lines and New Power Dynamics
item.description: Smaller countries see Germany’s domestic largess to tackle spiraling energy costs as undermining the effort to lower fuel prices for the wider European Union.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Energy facilities at Wilhelmshaven, a German hub for liquefied natural gas imports. Critics say Germany should prioritize lowering the price of natural gas for the whole E.U., instead of maneuvering to secure more for itself.

item.title: Putin’s 70th Birthday Is Hailed in Russia and Derided in Ukraine
item.description: Russian newspapers lauded Mr. Putin’s leadership, comparing him to Peter the Great and Leonid Brezhnev. Some Ukrainians said they hoped the birthday would be his last.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova and Megan Specia
item.media:description: A visitor stands next to Alexey Sergienko’s painting called “Putin with a Puppy,” presented on the eve of the 70th birthday of Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, in St. Petersburg on Thursday.

item.title: An Abortion Ban With Unexpected Consequences for Older Mothers
item.description: Older women are more likely to carry fetuses with genetic disorders that often can’t be detected until 15 weeks of pregnancy, beyond the limit set in a Senate proposal.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Ashbey Beasley, in orange, a mother who found that her fetus had an anomaly after 16 weeks, confronted Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina as he unveiled his abortion bill last month.

item.title: Julia Becomes a Tropical Storm After Making Landfall in Nicaragua
item.description: The storm made landfall as a hurricane in Nicaragua early on Sunday, where it was expected to bring heavy rainfall that could trigger dangerous flash flooding and mudslides, forecasters said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: Evacuees in Bluefields, Nicaragua, as Hurricane Julia struck. Forecasters warned of life-threatening flash floods and mudslides from heavy rains over Central America through the weekend.

item.title: Who Is Ales Bialiatski, the Belarusian Nobel Peace Prize Laureate?
item.description: Ales Bialiatski was part of a dissident group that helped lay the groundwork in the late Soviet period for a movement calling for the independence of Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ales Bialiatski, a Belarusian rights activist, speaking at a Right Livelihood Award event in Stockholm in 2020.

item.title: In Ukraine, Sharing the Nobel Peace Prize Prompts Backlash
item.description: Some saw the decision to group a Ukrainian organization with human rights defenders from Russia and Belarus — two of the country’s aggressors — as an affront.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Distributing aid to civilians in the recently liberated city of Izium, in the eastern Kharkiv region of Ukraine, last week.

item.title: A Canadian Family Is Seeing the World Before Their Children’s Vision Falters
item.description: A Canadian family is on a yearlong journey across Asia and Africa because three of their four children have an eye condition that causes blindness.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Ukraine’s Center for Civil Liberties Among 2022 Nobel Peace Prize Winners
item.description: While the invasion added greater urgency to their work, the group has been tracking disappearances and war crimes for years.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A protester among a group of Center for Civil Liberties activists and representatives of the L.G.B.T.Q. community outside the Cabinet of Ministers building in Kyiv in 2020.

item.title: The Power of Paxlovid
item.description: The underuse of Covid treatments is leading to many needless deaths.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Memorial, a Nobel Peace Prize Winner, Has Been Targeted by Putin in Russia
item.description: The organization “is based on the notion that confronting past crimes is essential in preventing new ones,” the Norwegian Nobel Committee said.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A demonstrator with a sign reading “Hands off Memorial” protested outside Russia’s Supreme Court in December as the court deliberated whether or dissolve Memorial.

item.title: Brittany Higgins Takes the Stand
item.description: The first week of the high profile trial in Australia has highlighted some of the difficulties of prosecuting sexual assault cases.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Brittany Higgins arriving to give evidence in front of an ACT Supreme Court jury on the third day of the trial of her alleged rapist, Bruce Lehrmann, in Canberra, Australia, on Thursday.

item.title: His Mom Labored on a Winery Under Apartheid. Now, He Owns One.
item.description: Paul Siguqa grew up hating wineries because his mother toiled in their fields. But last year he opened the only fully Black-owned vineyard in Franschhoek, one of South Africa’s most prestigious wine towns.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Tommy Trenchard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Siguqa, owner of the Klein Goederust winery, inspecting a glass of his cabernet-merlot blend.

item.title: So You Want to Work Remotely: A Guide
item.description: As more employers offer flexibility, countries, travel brands and entrepreneurs are stepping in to make working from anywhere easier, with everything from special visas to work pods.
item.dc:creator: Nora Walsh

item.title: How Iranians in New York Are Helping the Protests Abroad
item.description: “It’s really been a very long process of suffering that has led to this moment,” one activist said.
item.dc:creator: Sasha von Oldershausen
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Earlier this week, a vigil took place at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn to show solidarity for protesters in Iran.
